------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C8AA99.88742390
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Amen to the time it takes conducting experiments!
 
Science is weeks of methodical, experimental tedium punctuated by a few
"Aha" moments.  The discussion regarding CPPNs, HyperNEAT and the boundaries
of the envelope have been tremendous.  I feel like I'm playing catch-up to
understand the some of the fundamental capabilities of HyperNEAT, when
compared with the rest of the group - but what I see is exciting indeed!
 
Ken Lloyd
 


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kenneth Stanley
Sent: Tuesday, April 29, 2008 5:15 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Machine Learning and the Long View of AI



--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "afcarl2"
<a.carl@...> wrote:
> 
> The lack of scientific/methodical approach in demonstrating ability 
> to discover patterns, a priori known patterns, before attempting to 
> demonstrate a "killer-application", for which there is no known 
> figure of merit to compare "ability to discover patterns", is 
> disturbing, and expecting an inordinate level of faith on the part of 
> the reader.
> 
> The lack of any comparative computational cost data is equally 
> disturbing, and begs the question, especially since there appears to 
> be a growing body of user experience that the computational cost is 
> steep. But the information should be up-front going in rather than 
> withheld and unanswered.

Andy, I'm trying to figure out what's bothering you. You express
impatience that every possible question has not been answered within
one year of the debut of a completely new methodology. It verges on
paranoia to suggest that we are "withholding" information (the source
code is released; anyone can perform any experiment that they wish). 
I suppose you just don't realize how much effort goes into running
experiments and writing papers. 

Notice that others in this group ask questions that are couched as
friendly discussion. Yet you take the attitude that someone is hiding
something from you and you are therefore "disturbed." 

You should change your tone. Instead of attacking the source for not
having answered every question that you have and performed every
experiment that you personally believe we should ever perform, why not
put it more like, "It would be interesting to see if..." or "One
experiment I'd like to perform is..." or "An interesting question is
whether..." In other words, what is accomplished by your aggressive,
confrontational demeanor?

I remember hearing once, though I do not remember the source, an
interesting quote on scientific research. To paraphrase: "Good
scientific research answers hard questions. However, the best
scientific research raises entirely new questions that we never could
have even asked before." Think of quantum physics. The uncertainty
principle has led to endless discussion of paradoxes and
impossibilities, with no end in sight, but we do not see people
accusing Heisenberg of trying to hide the "truth." Instead, it is a
credit to his discovery that we are now asking such profound questions.

So let me suggest to you that you change your tone and drop the
confrontational demeanor. That is not an appropriate way to speak to
colleagues, or to anyone else for that matter, and I sincerely hope to
maintain the exceptional positive atmosphere this group has maintained
throughout 5 years (believe it or not!) of fruitful and interesting
discussion.

Let me also add that I am not the moderator (who is Derek James, who
has done an excellent job), and therefore this is just my personal
suggestion.

ken



 


------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C8AA99.88742390
